Explanation: The doctor effectively addressed the chief complaint of bedwetting by asking relevant questions about its onset, frequency, associated symptoms, and family history.

The doctor effectively inquired about the onset of the bedwetting issue by asking if it was the first time it had been a problem and when it started, leading to the patient revealing that it began a few months ago.
The doctor did not specifically ask about the frequency of bedwetting episodes, which is crucial to understand the severity of the issue.
The doctor effectively asked about changes in daily routine and stress at home or school, which led to the patient revealing that the bedwetting started after beginning a new school.
The doctor specifically asked about fluid intake before bedtime, which led to the patient revealing that he drinks a lot of water before bed.
The doctor did not specifically ask about daytime urinary symptoms or any issues the patient may have experienced during the day.
The doctor did not ask any questions related to bowel habits during the history taking.

The doctor specifically asked about sleep patterns and whether the patient wakes up to go to the bathroom, which directly pertains to the patient's ability to sleep through the night without interruption.
The doctor specifically asked about family history of bedwetting or other urinary issues, which led to the patient revealing that his father had similar issues as a child.

The doctor effectively inquired about the patient's past medical history by asking if there had been any recent illnesses or significant medical conditions, which led to the patient confirming no significant medical history.
The doctor did not inquire about developmental milestones or any aspects of Ethan's developmental history, which are important for assessing normal development.
The doctor effectively inquired about changes in daily routine and stress at home or school, which directly relates to the psychosocial stressor of starting a new school.

The doctor did not specifically ask about the patient's diet or any recent changes to it; the conversation focused more on fluid intake before bed rather than a comprehensive assessment of the patient's overall diet.
The doctor did not ask any questions regarding current medications during the history-taking conversation.
The doctor did not ask any questions related to the patient's past surgical history during the conversation.
The doctor specifically asked about allergies, which led to the patient confirming that they do not have any known allergies.
